results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film, titled ‘Our Garden’, Kenneth introduces us to the Rankine house (exterior) and garden as well as family and friends meeting and greeting the camera, playing ball games, showing off the family pet rabbit and dog and finally. This reel also introduces Bob Wootton who will marry daughter Bettye Rankine. Kenneth includes lingering shots of flowers which often feature throughout his films, often to separate his scenes. There are some great examples of the style and textiles of the clothes of the era and the family cars that feature in Kenneth’s reels. As proof that Bob Wootton is now in the family, Kenneth directs a kiss between him and his future mother-in-law to end the reel.

Selected highlights list:

00:04:12:00 women of the house posing in matching frocks and dodging bees where Kenneth has them pose.

00:04:27:00 the women eating watermelon.

00:04:54:00 one of the women wearing a uniform (possible of the WAAAF).

00:06:30:00 example of 1940 style dress with gloves and bag.
00:07:04:00 another uniform shot interspersed with flowers and the pet rabbit.

00:08:51:00 fruit trees are another feature of the garden and whilst collecting apricots, apples and green beans we see some examples of two piece sunsuits of the day.

00:14:11:00 title card ‘Peter’ begins a sequence featuring the family pet rabbit.

00:16:18:00 shows Mrs Rankine in a large black car in the driveway before shots of the lawns covered in hailstones or sleet.

00:16:31:00 title card ‘Kim’ introduces us to the family dog and to a young Bob Wootton who would become part of the family when married to Kenneth’s daughter.

00:17:30:00 title card ‘His First Bath’ shows the dog being washed in two enamel bowls typical of the time.

00:18:36:00 car being driven by Bob Wootton and members of the family in or near the car and playing with Kim.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film contains scenes taken of the Rankine/Wootton children, filmed primarily at play in a garden. We see the children grow as the film tracks their growth over 3 years. Kenneth uses shots of flowers, trees and leaves throughout to separate scenes.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:10:00 title card “Now I am 3 & Look at Elizabeth 9 months”.

00:00:49:00 baby Elizabeth wearing a hat while sitting strapped into a coach-built pram.

00:01:27:00 family picnic, complete with picnic rug, wicker baskets, thermos flasks and folding chairs.

00:02:14:00 children in the garden shows us excellent examples of hand made and hand knitted children’s clothes. The images of Elizabeth at play show what fun small children can have with just a cardboard box.

00:03:52:00 close-up of a butterfly on foliage.

00:04:47:00 the children have grown and the eldest child is off to school as shown by his schoolbag. The Reel ends with a close-up of dad and the kids.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film begins with the title ‘Beauty in Victoria’ which is Kenneth’s reference to the beauty that includes nature, the Queen, a ‘bathing beauty’ contest and city night lights. Titles for the reel also include ‘Visit the Buchan Caves’ with specific directions to a ‘Modern Camp Site’ both of which introduce a lengthy look at the Buchan area. The reel ends with a quick look at ‘Port Campbell’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:28:00 on the way to the caves, the Rankines make a stop at the Caves Hotel where Mrs Rankine keeps an eye on a magpie alongside the family car which as always, features in Kenneth’s travel footage.

00:00:39:00 the camp site is within the ‘Buchan Caves National Park’ whcih is well signed on an overhead stone archway.

00:00:49:00 begins a sequence of shots that show off the ‘modern’ camp site. We see the ‘A E LIND’ Swimming Pool, the various amenities and stone and timber buildings of the camp area such as the ‘Children’s Playground’, ‘Kitchen’ and ‘Carwash’. We also see a wonderful red truck of the era and plenty of wandering sheep.

00:01:55:00 we see Mrs Rankine at the ‘Royal Cave’ entrance.

00:02:26:00 a sequence of farmland views and shots of a bluetongue lizard.

00:03:27:00 title ‘Coronation Week’ begins with a picture of the Queen followed by various buildings decorated in British colours of red, white and blue.

00:03:58:00 decorated Palais theatre and Luna Park at St Kilda.

00:04:41:00 Melbourne city streets and department stores such as a highly decorated Myer and Foy’s departments stores, and the Queen’s name across the Elizabeth St entrance to the Flinders St Station.

00:05:30:00 Kenneth begins a nightlights sequence to show the decorations in neon.

00:09:33:00 ‘The Sun Beach Girl Finals’ where Kenneth films the parade and judges without filming the winner but showing the popularity of these events.

00:14:04:00 title ‘Port Campbell’ and brief views of the windy, rocky coastline and dramatic waves.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows the Australian ‘outback’, focussing on Alice Springs. The start of the reel has shots of roads, erosion alongside the roads, surrounding countryside and distant views as well as Kenneth’s car on the road - an image he often used to indicate the film will capture a roadtrip.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 starts with a title card ‘Hello Alice’.

00:31:00:00 Map of Australia honing in on Alice Springs.

00:46:00:00 sign ‘Pichi Richi Pass - Caution - Creeks and Corners’.

00:1:09:0000:01:47:00 we sight a small steam train.

00:02:10:00 a rail bridge.

00:02:38:00 travellers arrive at the township of Quorn (South Australia)

00:03:01:00 the Quorn train station; long transport steam trains. sign for the township of Marree.

00:04:15:00 footage includes looking at the wheels and tracks, passengers awaiting trains, local Indigenous people, scenes of the outback taken from the train.

00:06:10:00 the traintrip reaches the township of Beresford and then the William Creek Hotel at 00:06:40:00 where we see passengers having fetched bottles of beer from the hotel sprinting back to the train.

00:06:50:00 a glimpse of (probably) brumbies and more scenes of locals and the surrounding countryside from travelling train.

00:09:27:00 we sight traindrivers or workers walking alongside the train, travel by a sheep station and through a very arid landscape.

00:10:20:00 the sign for Alice Springs comes into view. Kenneth starts a tour of the town with some police officers speaking to the camera and footage of families and their cars in one of the streets. Footage includes wandering around the wide dusty roads, people walking and on bicycles and then a look at the buildings - houses, a focus on an older building made (unusually of brick), eucalyptus trees and a flowering garden,

00:11:33:00 we see a sign for the ‘Australian Inland Mission Hostel for bush mothers and children’ on a building that Kenneth gives us several views of including a motorbike outside. This is followed by a view of a new and very modern looking building, surrounded by vegetable or market gardens and out front of which Mrs Rankine chats with acquaintances who point her up to a monument on a hill.

00:12:10:00 is a view from the monument, overlooking the town including views of its oval and what appears to be a prison.

00:13:19:00 view of eucalypts in the surrounding landscape.

00:13:40:00 we see a marker for ‘Flynn’s Grave’ which is a beautiful boulder perched on a stone pedestal.

00:14:04:00 a sign for ‘Standley Chasm’ appears and begins a sequence of dramatic and beautiful scenes of rocky outcrops, foliage and trees. Kenneth films some walkers among the rocks which shows the size and context of the environment.

00:15:31:00 we see two Indigenous horsemen followed by a sign for ‘Hermannsberg’ and some shots of the mission church building, some members of the community and a group of children smiling for the camera. The reel ends with some last looks at the landscape.
results.title_for_label: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 23]
results.description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows the Australian ‘outback’, focussing on Alice Springs. The start of the reel has shots of roads, erosion alongside the roads, surrounding countryside and distant views as well as Kenneth’s car on the road - an image he often used to indicate the film will capture a roadtrip.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 starts with a title card ‘Hello Alice’.

00:31:00:00 Map of Australia honing in on Alice Springs.

00:46:00:00 sign ‘Pichi Richi Pass - Caution - Creeks and Corners’.

00:1:09:0000:01:47:00 we sight a small steam train.

00:02:10:00 a rail bridge.

00:02:38:00 travellers arrive at the township of Quorn (South Australia)

00:03:01:00 the Quorn train station; long transport steam trains. sign for the township of Marree.

00:04:15:00 footage includes looking at the wheels and tracks, passengers awaiting trains, local Indigenous people, scenes of the outback taken from the train.

00:06:10:00 the traintrip reaches the township of Beresford and then the William Creek Hotel at 00:06:40:00 where we see passengers having fetched bottles of beer from the hotel sprinting back to the train.

00:06:50:00 a glimpse of (probably) brumbies and more scenes of locals and the surrounding countryside from travelling train.

00:09:27:00 we sight traindrivers or workers walking alongside the train, travel by a sheep station and through a very arid landscape.

00:10:20:00 the sign for Alice Springs comes into view. Kenneth starts a tour of the town with some police officers speaking to the camera and footage of families and their cars in one of the streets. Footage includes wandering around the wide dusty roads, people walking and on bicycles and then a look at the buildings - houses, a focus on an older building made (unusually of brick), eucalyptus trees and a flowering garden,

00:11:33:00 we see a sign for the ‘Australian Inland Mission Hostel for bush mothers and children’ on a building that Kenneth gives us several views of including a motorbike outside. This is followed by a view of a new and very modern looking building, surrounded by vegetable or market gardens and out front of which Mrs Rankine chats with acquaintances who point her up to a monument on a hill.

00:12:10:00 is a view from the monument, overlooking the town including views of its oval and what appears to be a prison.

00:13:19:00 view of eucalypts in the surrounding landscape.

00:13:40:00 we see a marker for ‘Flynn’s Grave’ which is a beautiful boulder perched on a stone pedestal.

00:14:04:00 a sign for ‘Standley Chasm’ appears and begins a sequence of dramatic and beautiful scenes of rocky outcrops, foliage and trees. Kenneth films some walkers among the rocks which shows the size and context of the environment.

00:15:31:00 we see two Indigenous horsemen followed by a sign for ‘Hermannsberg’ and some shots of the mission church building, some members of the community and a group of children smiling for the camera. The reel ends with some last looks at the landscape.

results.title: A Visit to Australia's Great Barrier Reef
results.brief_description:
This film tours of the waters around the Great Barrier Reef showing corals, fish, turtles and other features of the Reef. A highlight of the footage is of local Indigenous people sharing their skills.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:05:00 title card ‘A visit to Australia’s Great Barrier Reef’.

00:13:00:00 further title cards ‘Photographed by Mr Tom C. Marshall’ and ‘Photographed on Kodakchrome Film’. Presumably Kenneth is not behind the camera on this reel as some of it is under water.

00:21:00:00 ‘Part I’ title card introduces footage of family members in shallow reef waters examining corals, at one point with a hand held viewer of some sort.

00:01:43:00 stripey fish appear.

00:03:04:00 parrot fish being examined in and out of the water with a close up of one being held up close, almost speaking to the camera.

00:03:54:00 clown fish and flathead swimming among the coral.

00:04:16:00 title card ‘Part II’ appears followed by a close up of a giant clam and various sea creatures crawling along the seabed floor.

00:05:03:00 footage of shell seekers and shell collections including giant species held up to the camera for close inspection.

00:06:40:00 very large colourful sea urchin held close to camera followed by a long legged starfish and several sea snakes or eels.

00:08:35:00 large sea slug and creatures on seabed floor camouflaged among corals.

00:09:30:00 turtle and baby turtles entering the sea; octopus shots.

00:11:04:00 (possibly) Shearwater sea birds (Mutton Birds) nesting in low lying trees; egg in nest held to camera.

00:12:00:00 waterbirds and seagulls; looking for birds and eggs.

00:13:03:00 title card ‘Part IV’ footage of an island, showing groups of Indigenous school children and young people.

00:14:03:00 local Indigenous person showing us how to climb a coconut palm, harvest and drop the nuts as well as skilfully stripping away the husks with their teeth before enjoying the juice; palm fronds are then harvested from the trees with machetes.

00:16:09:00 weaving baskets from the split fronds.

results.title: [London, 1963 - 1964]
results.brief_description:
This silent, black-and-white footage of some of the major landmarks of London was shot in 1963–1964 by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett.

Opens with the Royal Marines Band playing, filmed as they march past the Duke of York Column and Waterloo Steps.

00:00:46:00 then Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Alec Douglas-Home, farewelling a visitor on the steps of Number 10 Downing Street (the headquarters of British government).

00:01:11:00 camera pans down Nelson’s Column (a monument in Trafalgar Square, central London, commemorating Admiral Horatio Nelson.) We then see scenes of Trafalgar Square, with the National Gallery building and fountain both visible.

00:01:22:00 camera lingers on the equestrian statue of King Charles I, with the church of St Martin-in-the-Fields in the background.

00:01:28:00 London traffic, with the camera focussing especially on cabs (taxis).

00:01:43:00 the Admiralty Arch.

00:01:49:00 double-decker London bus in front of some classic 1960’s style adverstising signs in Piccadilly Circus, with the Eros statue visible.

00:02:04:00 Eros statue in close-up.

00:02:22:00 Underground (railway) sign in close-up, followed by scenes in the Underground itself; ticket queues, escalators, and a train coming into a platform.

00:02:46:00 “Piccadilly Circus” station sign visible on the wall of the train tunnel

The film ends with footage of the tunnel, shot from the moving train.

group_siblings.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]

production_dates.notes: Creation date recorded on donated film can.

results.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]
results.brief_description:
The Fletcher Jones factory and Gardens at 61–81 Flaxman Street, Warrnambool (established 1948) are famous local landmarks and symbolic of the radical approach to industrial relations and the provision of workplace amenities taken by the famous Australian company. The complex, including the Water Tower, was listed on the Victorian Heritage Register in 2006 in recognition of its historic and social significance which notes “…the unusual and successful integration of surplus military structures, buildings and modernist facade in a factory setting. They reflect the resourcefulness and dynamism of Fletcher Jones in the use of war surplus structures and objects during a time of building material shortages.”

The forty-metre-high water tower – built for fire protection and as a booster system – was designed and supervised by Ralph Jones Construction Engineering Services between 1965–1967. [Source: University of Melbourne Archives: Ralph Jones Water Tower Submission and Business Papers].

This silent, black-and-white footage of the tower’s construction was photographed by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett. It is a unique historic documentary record of the construction of an iconic feature of Warrnambool’s – and Victoria’s – industrial heritage.

results.title: Mots' Mansion [videogame trailer]
results.brief_description: Special Mention in the Middle Videogame category. Sam, Bec and their Mother move in to Grandma’s house. But when Bec is captured, Sam needs to complete tasks given to him by the mysterious MOTS. Can he trust the Man on the Stairs and will they both make it out. In the end, the choices you make will matter.

results.title: Day One [videogame trailer]
results.brief_description: Winner in the Middle Videogame. In 2017, tens of thousands of Australians will battle the greatest mystery of their lives … high school. In ‘Day One’, your mission is to survive your first day of high school. You will need to find your seat in assembly, learn a new instrument, escape detention, sprint 100 metres, destroy a vending machine, and dodge rubbish bins to ultimately find your classroom.

In ‘Day One’, your mission is to survive your first day of high school. You will need to find your seat in assembly, learn a new instrument, escape detention, sprint 100 metres, destroy a vending machine, and dodge rubbish bins to ultimately find your classroom.
description_for_label: Winner in the Middle Videogame. In 2017, tens of thousands of Australians will battle the greatest mystery of their lives … high school. In ‘Day One’, your mission is to survive your first day of high school. You will need to find your seat in assembly, learn a new instrument, escape detention, sprint 100 metres, destroy a vending machine, and dodge rubbish bins to ultimately find your classroom.
